semantic_title: Default Codes - Most Common or Unspecified Code for Main Term
section_path: Section I > A. Conventions > 18. Default codes

content.full_text: A code listed next to a main term in the ICD-10-CM Alphabetic Index is referred to as a default code. The default code represents that condition that is most commonly associated with the main term or is the unspecified code for the condition. If a condition is documented in a medical record (for example, appendicitis) without any additional information, such as acute or chronic, the default code should be assigned. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L70-L72)
content.summary: Default codes represent the most common or unspecified form of a condition and should be used when no additional specificity is documented (Evidence: pg no: 12, L70-L72)
key_concepts: Code listed next to main term (Evidence: pg no: 12, L70-L71)
Most commonly associated condition (Evidence: pg no: 12, L71)
Unspecified code for condition (Evidence: pg no: 12, L71-L72)
Used when no additional information available (Evidence: pg no: 12, L72)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Default code should be assigned when condition documented without additional information (Evidence: pg no: 12, L72)
detailed_rules.explanation: When documentation lacks specificity like acute or chronic, use the default code (Evidence: pg no: 12, L72)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Locate main term in Alphabetic Index
Step 2: Identify code listed next to main term
Step 3: Check if additional specificity is documented
Step 4: Use default code if no additional information
Step 5: Use more specific code if additional details available

code_patterns.description: Code immediately following main term in Alphabetic Index (Evidence: pg no: 12, L70-L71)
code_patterns.explanation: Represents most common or unspecified form

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient diagnosed with appendicitis without additional specificity
step_by_step: Step 1: Look up Appendicitis in Alphabetic Index
Step 2: Note default code next to main term
Step 3: Check documentation for additional details
Step 4: Use default code since no specificity provided

correct_coding.rationale: No additional information provided, so default code appropriate (Evidence: pg no: 12, L72)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should not assume specificity not documented

breakdown.Default code: Most common or unspecified form of appendicitis (Evidence: pg no: 12, L71-L72)

best_practices: Use default code when no additional information is documented (Evidence: pg no: 12, L72)

tips: Default codes are immediately next to main terms
Represent most common or unspecified forms
